<h1><a id="user-content-abstract" class="anchor" href="#abstract" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Abstract</h1>

<p>A fundamental challenge for individuals who rely on the extraction of natural
resources for their livelihood is income variability. Fishers, loggers, farmers,
and miners, among others, face high levels of income uncertainty driven by a mix
of environmental, biological, and economic variability. A key component
underlying the sustainability of these industries is identifying both how
regulatory actions and individual behaviour affect income variability and by
extension the economic stability and sustainable use of natural resources. For
commercial fisheries, recent work has identified that targeting a diversity of
species can reduce income variability. However, any diversity-variability
relationship is embedded in a regulatory framework that restricts individual
ability to change fishing behaviour. Here we identify three primary axes by
which fishers in Alaska, one of the world's most productive fishery regions, can
potentially diversify fishing activities and investigate how individual actions
along each diversity axis affect both revenue and revenue variability. We
construct a novel statistical model to simultaneously assess the value to
individual fishers of choosing to (1) own permits that allow targeting a diverse
fish species assemblage, (2) diversify by owning multiple permits, or (3) catch
a greater species diversity within the constraints of a given permit. We show
contrasting effects of diversity on revenue and revenue variability along the
three axes. First, we show that fishing permits with higher species diversity
reduces variability (<code>r h1[[2]]</code>% [<code>r h1[[1]]</code>--<code>r h1[[3]]</code>% 95% CI] reduction
per unit increase in mean effective species diversity). Next, we show that
fishing an additional permit is associated with higher revenue and lower
variability (e.g., <code>r 100-spoke[[2]]</code>% [<code>r 100-spoke[[3]]</code>--<code>r 100-spoke[[1]]</code>%
IQR] lower expected standard deviation for halibut plus another permit vs.
single halibut permits). Finally, we show that increasing species diversity
within the constraints of a permit set has a fishery-dependent effect on revenue
and is usually (<code>r g2_dens</code>% probability) associated with increased uncertainty
in revenue the following year. Thus, while there are clear benefits to some axes
of diversification, others are less effective. Importantly, the most effective
measure for increasing revenue and decreasing risk --- purchasing additional
permits to participate in additional fisheries --- was also the most costly. At
the same time, Alaskan commercial fisheries have been increasingly focussed on
single-permit (often salmon) fishing strategies. Our results suggest that the
benefit of species diversity for revenue variability is mostly an across-permit
effect, not a benefit that can be easily harnessed by an individual permit
holder. Effective methods of diversification --- purchasing additional permits
or switching permits --- are costly and often limited by regulations such as
limited entry programs and individual transferable quotas (ITQs). Take home ...</p>

<p>\bigskip
\noindent</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-introduction" class="anchor" href="#introduction" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Introduction</h1>



<p>Managing natural resources and sustaining the livelihoods of those that depend
on their extraction is difficult. These professions tend to have high
year-to-year variability in income [@mishra2002; @sethi2012b]. In addition to
economic risk, such as changes in demand, individuals dependent on natural
resources are also subject to biological and environmental variability. For
example, drought and flooding are a major source of risk to agricultural food
security and farmers' incomes [@gregory2005], and catastrophic disease outbreaks
and wildfires increase risk for the logging industry [@kirilenko2007].</p>

<p>Individuals who rely on natural resources for income develop strategies to
reduce income variability. For example, farmers may rotate their crops to buffer
short-term climate variation and long-term environmental trends [@zentner1988].
Similarly, loggers maintain a diverse mix of tree species, age structure, and
harvest in geographical areas to buffer against disease outbreak, wildfires, and
price variation REF. However, otherwise well-intentioned regulations can limit
the actions available to individuals to reduce income variability, or
incentivize against diversification. For example, in terrestrial agriculture,
crop subsidies in the US may incentivize some farms to specialize (e.g. dairy,
grains, soybeans; @mishra2002). In other instances, external market forces
(prices, demand) may discourage the adoption of diverse strategies and help
promote specialization [@bradshaw2004]. </p>

<p>Commercial fishers present an interesting example of diversification, given the
extreme risk that some individuals experience, particularly relative to
terrestrial agriculture [@sethi2012b]. The majority of insurance programs
available to terrestrial farmers (e.g. crop insurance programs) are not
available to commercial fishers [@kasperski2013] and both fish and fishers are
spatially mobile. However, fishers still have the ability to lower risk. They
can, for example, target multiple species as permitted by a license, own
multiple licenses, or diversify spatially and fish in multiple regions. The
effectiveness of these diversification strategies for improving revenue and
reducing revenue variability remains uncertain. Furthermore, theory and
empirical studies both suggest there can be substantial benefits to
specialization (REFS). The majority of papers that examine effects of
diversification on revenue do so at aggregate levels (e.g. households, counties,
communities; REFS), rather than focus on individuals. Because of this, key
uncertainties remain about the fundamental relationship between diversity,
fishing revenue, and fishing revenue variability at the level of the individual.</p>

<p>The state and federal fisheries of Alaska provide a unique opportunity to
understand the role of individuals' strategies in determining income and income
variability for those whose livelihood depends on the extraction of natural
resources. Fisheries in Alaska are among the highest-valued fisheries in the
world with 2.7 billion kg landed biomass valued at nearly 2 billion USD annually
[@nmfs2016]. The industry supports a range of fishing fleets ranging from small,
open, single-operator vessels to multi-million-dollar state-of-the-art ships
with large crews. Like much of the rest of the world [@hilborn2003a], the days
of open, unregulated fisheries in most developed countries have passed ---
fishers must own a license to participate in virtually all fisheries. And while
such regulations have proven helpful in reducing or eliminating overfishing,
they limit the available strategies to reduce income variability. For example,
many permits limit fishing to a single species, diversifying by purchasing
additional fishing permits can be expensive (e.g. ~\$XX for king crab), and some
fisheries limit the entry of new participants through individual fishing quotas
(IFQs) (REF). </p>

<p>Using a unique dataset collected over 30 years (1985--2014) on individuals,
rather than fleets or vessels, we examine how revenue and revenue variability of
individuals is affected by diversification. By tracking individuals rather than
vessels we can track people that switch fishery sectors over time, or alter
strategies and use multiple vessels. We develop and apply a hierarchical
Bayesian model to understand the effect of diversity on both individual revenue
and revenue variability that builds on results from vessel [@kasperski2013],
fleet [@sethi2012b], and community-level [@sethi2014] variability. Our model
controls for fishing effort and latent time effects (e.g. changing environmental
conditions), simultaneously estimates the effect of species diversity on
individual revenue and revenue variability, and estimates effects both within
and across fishing strategies (sets of similar licenses or permits). To our
knowledge, this is the first application of this type of model in any natural
resource field.</p>

<p>\clearpage</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-methods" class="anchor" href="#methods" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Methods</h1>

<p>We developed a hierarchical variance-function regression model [@davidian1987;
@hall1989], which separately models changes in the mean and variance of
individual revenue as a function of covariates. Whereas traditional
hierarchical linear models assume homoscedasticity --- that the residual
variance does not vary systematically --- the variance-function regression model
allows the variance to be heteroscedastic and vary as a function of predictors.
Our specific model allows certain fishing strategies and levels of species
diversification to generate more or less revenue and be more or less variable
than others.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-data" class="anchor" href="#data" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Data</h2>

<p>We obtained commercial fisheries landings and revenue data for all permit
holders in Alaska from <code>r range_yrs[1]</code> to <code>r range_yrs[2]</code> from the Alaskan
Commercial Fisheries Entry Commission (CFEC). These data represent a total of
nearly <code>r round(ndat$initial_tot_rev/1e9)</code> billion 2009 USD and a combined <code>r 
round(ndat$initial/1e6,1)</code> million rows of data. We adjusted for inflation by
setting all revenues to 2009 USD [@bea2016]. We implemented a number of
filtering steps to focus on individuals actively engaged in commercial fishing
(Supporting Information). In particular, we removed permit holders whose median
revenue was less than \$10,000 2009 USD to focus on individuals for whom
commercial fishing formed a substantial part of their income.</p>

<p>We combined similar permits into permit groupings and identified sets of permit
groupings held by an individual in a specific year as "strategies" (Supporting
Information). For example, we combined permits that were the same except for
vessel size (e.g. a longliner fishing sablefish on a vessel under 60 ft was
considered to have the same strategy as a longliner fishing sablefish on
a vessel over 60 ft), and we combined a number of permits that were targeting
a single species and differed only in region fished. Therefore, for example,
someone fishing herring roe in Kodiak and someone fishing herring roe in Alaska
Peninsula were both considered to have a 'herring roe' permit group. For salmon
permits, we grouped permits using the same gear type across regions for groups
that shared similar species composition. After this process of combining
permits, we were left with <code>r n_grouped_permits</code> unique fishing permit groups
(Table S\ref{tab:strategies}), which we aggregated within each person-year
combination to form permit strategies. For example, if someone fished halibut
and sablefish in the same year, their strategy for that year would be
"halibut-sablefish". Specific details on our strategy definitions are available
in the Supporting Information.</p>

<p>Our models focused on species diversity as a possible predictor of revenue and
revenue variability while controlling for effort. For consistency with previous
analyses [@kasperski2013], we calculated effective species diversity for
permit holder $i$ and time (year) $t$ as the inverse of Simpson's diversity
index $\lambda$ <a href="/NCEAS/pfx-commercial/blob/master/portfolio/text/also%20referred%20to%20in%20economics%20as%20the%0AHerfindahl-Hirschman%20Index">@simpson1949; @jost2006</a> weighted by revenue $R$:</p>

<p>\begin{equation}
1/\lambda_{i,t} = 1 / \left(\sum\limits_{s=1}^{n_{i,t}}
  \left(R_{i,s,t}/ \sum\limits_{s=1}^{n_{i,t}} R_{i,s,t}\right)\right)^2,
\end{equation}</p>

<p>\noindent where $s$ indexes species from $1$ through $n$. We calculated effort
or effective season length as the sum of the season lengths for each permit each
year. Season length for a given permit was calculated as the number of days
between the first instance of fishing a permit and the last instance of fishing
a permit each year. For example, if someone fished for 30 days on a salmon drift
gillnet permit in Southeast Alaska and 40 days on a statewide longline halibut
permit, that individual's season length would be 70 days.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-hierarchical-model" class="anchor" href="#hierarchical-model" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Hierarchical model</h2>

<p>To jointly model revenue and revenue variability as a function of
individual-level covariates, we extended the basic variance-function regression
to a hierarchical Bayesian variance-function regression model with Gaussian
errors predicting $\log$ revenue, $\log(R_{i,t})$, for each fisher $i$ and time
$t$:</p>

<p>\begin{equation}
\log(R_{i,t}) \sim \mathrm{N} \left(\widehat{\log(R_{i,t})}, \widehat{\sigma_{i,t}^2} \right).
\end{equation}</p>

<p>\noindent Each year $t$ of revenue for fisher $i$ is assigned a strategy indexed
by $j$ (Supporting Information, Table \ref{tab:strategies}) and expected
$\log(R_{i,t})$ is modelled as:</p>







<p>\begin{equation}
\label{eq:mean}
\widehat{\log(R_{i,t})} = \beta_{0,j,t} -
  \beta_{1,j} S_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
  \beta_{2,j} S_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
  \beta_3 D_{i,t} -
  \beta_4 S_{i,t} D_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
  \beta_5 S_{i,t} D_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
  \log(R_{i,t-1}),
\end{equation}</p>

<p>\noindent where $S_{i,t}$ is the percent change in species diversity, $\log
\left(\mathrm{div}<em>{i,t}/\mathrm{div}</em>{i,t-1}\right)$, $D_{i,t}$ is the percent
change in days fished, $\log
\left(\mathrm{days}<em>{i,t}/\mathrm{days}</em>{i,t-1}\right)$, and $I_{i,t}$ is an
indicator variable that takes a value $0$ if $\mathrm{div}<em>{i,t} \ge
\mathrm{div}</em>{i,t-1}$ (species diversity increasing; generalizing) and takes
a value $1$ if $\mathrm{div}<em>{i,t} &lt; \mathrm{div}</em>{i,t-1}$ (species diversity
decreasing; specializing). Estimating a separate coefficient for the effect of
increasing diversity and decreasing diversity allows the costs and benefits of
these changes to be asymmetric.</p>

<p>We use $\log(R_{i,t-1}$) as an offset, and thus our model describes the percent
change in revenue, i.e., $\log(R_{i,t}) - \log(R_{i,t-1})
= \log(R_{i,t}/R_{i,t-1})$. We model change in revenue because preliminary
analysis revealed non-stationary trends in revenue (resulting from experience or
other unmodeled factors). This approach eliminates having to deal with the
non-stationary time series and eliminates having to estimate thousands of
mean-revenue intercepts associated with individual fishers. We removed
person-year combinations without a subsequent year of revenue.</p>

<p>The $\beta$ terms represent estimated coefficients, some of which are allowed to
vary as "random effect" terms. The intercepts $\beta_{0,j,t}$ are allowed to
vary by strategy-year combinations, are centered on zero, and are constrained by
a normal distribution:</p>



<p>\begin{equation}
\beta_{0,j,t} \sim \mathrm{N} \left(0, \sigma^2_{\beta_{j,t}} \right).
\end{equation}</p>

<p>\noindent This approach, combined with the lack of a global intercept,
constrains the mean change in log revenue across all fishers and years to be
zero. I.e., we assume that the data are stationary after accounting for all
covariates and including an intercept that varies with strategy-year
combinations. Initial versions of the model confirmed that the global intercept
along with strategy-level intercepts would be estimated at almost exactly zero.</p>

<p>The slopes $\beta_{1,j}$ and $\beta_{1,j}$ are then allowed to vary by strategy
with estimated means:</p>

<p>\begin{align}
\beta_{1,j} &amp;\sim \mathrm{N} \left(\mu_{\beta_1}, \sigma^2_{\beta_1}\right),\
\beta_{2,j} &amp;\sim \mathrm{N} \left(\mu_{\beta_2}, \sigma^2_{\beta_2}\right).
\end{align}</p>

<p>\noindent The $\beta_{1,j}$'s represent how much a 1\% decrease in species
diversity within a strategy translates to a Y\% change in revenue. The
$\beta_{2,j}$'s represent how much a 1\% increase in species diversity within
a strategy translates to a Y\% change in revenue. These are after controlling
for percent change in days fished, $\beta_3$, and the interaction between days
fished and percent change in species diversity, $\beta_4$ and $\beta_5$.</p>

<p>Whereas a typical hierarchical linear regression model would estimate a single
residual error scale term, $\sigma$, we model the scale of the residual error
with another hierarchical model with a similar form:</p>

<p>\begin{equation}
\label{eq:cv}
\widehat{\sigma_{i,t}} =
\exp \left( \gamma_{0,j} -
\gamma_{1,j} S_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
\gamma_{2,j} S_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
\gamma_3 D_{i,t} -
\gamma_4 S_{i,t} D_{i,t} I_{i,t} +
\gamma_5 S_{i,t} D_{i,t} I_{i,t}\right).
\end{equation}</p>

<p>\noindent Again, $S_{i,t}$ and $I_{i,t}$ represent, respectively, percent change
in species diversity and an indicator variable for increasing or decreasing
species diversity. We exponentiate the equation to ensure all scale parameters,
$\sigma_{i,t}$, are positive. The $\gamma$'s are estimated coefficients, three
of which are allowed to vary by strategy, constrained by normal distributions:</p>

<p>\begin{align}
\gamma_{0,j}  &amp;\sim \mathrm{N} \left(\eta_0 + \eta_1 M_j + \eta_2 E_j, \sigma^2_{\gamma_0}\right),\
\gamma_{1,j}  &amp;\sim \mathrm{N} \left(\mu_{\gamma_1}, \sigma^2_{\gamma_1}\right),\
\gamma_{2,j}  &amp;\sim \mathrm{N} \left(\mu_{\gamma_2}, \sigma^2_{\gamma_2}\right).
\end{align}</p>

<p>\noindent The mean of the $\gamma_{0,j}$ coefficients is modelled with two
strategy-level predictors. The symbols $M_j$ and $E_j$ represent the raw mean
species diversity and mean combined fishing season length (effort) for strategy
$j$. The coefficients $\eta_1$ and $\eta_2$ represent predictors in this
strategy-level regression estimating effects across strategies.</p>

<p>We fit our models with Stan 2.11.1 [@hoffman2014; @standevelopmentteam2015;
@standevelopmentteam2015a; @carpenter2015] and R 3.3.1 [@rcoreteam2016]. Stan
implements the No-U-Turn Hamiltonian Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm
[@hoffman2014] to perform Bayesian statistical inference. We assigned weakly
informative priors on all parameters: $N(0, 2^2)$ priors on all $\beta$,
$\gamma$, and $\eta$ parameters, and half-$t(3, 0, 2)$ priors (i.e. degrees of
freedom of 3 and scale of 2) on all $\sigma$ parameters to allow for heavier
tails. We ran four chains and 2,000 iterations and discarded the first 1,000
iterations of each chain as warm up (i.e. 4,000 final samples). We checked for
chain convergence visually with trace plots. We also ensured that $\hat{R}&lt;1.05$
(the potential scale reduction factor) and that the effective sample size, as
calculated by the rstan R package [@standevelopmentteam2015], was greater than
200 for all parameters [@gelman2014]. We verified that our model returned
sensible estimates by comparing our estimates to an ad-hoc two-stage model fit
with the lme4 R package [@bates2015], and by fitting our model to simulated data
and recovering the true values (Supporting Information). Code to reproduce our
results (with a simulated data set) is available at
.</p>

<p><em>TODO: for the following into the results section or and the method section with
this:</em></p>

<p>Residuals from the mean component of our model clearly show the "V"-shaped
pattern that the variance component of our model seeks to capture (Fig.
S\ref{fig:resid}). Furthermore, the downside residuals (year-individual data
points with lower than expected revenue) look qualitatively similar to the
complete set of residuals (upside and downside) (Fig.
S\ref{fig:resid-downside}). Therefore, it seemed appropriate to model the
variability as a proxy for revenue risk. </p>

<p>The estimated year-permit intercepts represent years when people with
a particular permit set in a given year tended to do better or worse than the
long-term average for that permit set (Fig. S\ref{fig:str-yrs}). Therefore, an
individual's expected revenue and variability is after accounting for the
general trend in revenue for that permit set.</p>

<p>Our model estimates overall average effects (Fig. S\ref{fig:fe}) and effects
that vary by permit set (Fig. S\ref{fig:re}).</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-results" class="anchor" href="#results" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Results</h1>

<p>We evaluated trends in revenue and diversification over time for individuals
fishing commercially in Alaska from 1985--2014 (Fig. \ref{fig:ts}A). The
majority (70--90%) of fishers hold single permits, with a slight increase in
single-permit holders since 2000 (Fig. \ref{fig:ts}C). This overall trend is
most sensitive to halibut or salmon permit holders --- compared to other
fisheries, halibut permit holders are more likely to hold halibut plus other
permits, whereas salmon permit holders are more likely to hold only one permit
(Fig. \ref{fig:ts}C). Despite making up only 10--30% of the individuals,
multiple permit holders make approximately half of the overall revenue (Fig.
\ref{fig:ts}B). The mean effective fished species diversity of this revenue
declined somewhat from 1980--2000 but has since remained steady (Fig.
\ref{fig:ts}D). However, this trend appears to be driven by an increase in
salmon specialists in the 1980s and 1990s --- the trend disappears if salmon
license holders are excluded (Fig. \ref{fig:ts}D).</p>

<p>Revenue variability decreases exponentially with higher mean fished species
diversity across permit sets (Fig. \ref{fig:across}). Controlling for effort,
strategies with one unit higher mean effective species diversity had on average
<code>r h1[[2]]</code>% (<code>r h1[[1]]</code>--<code>r h1[[3]]</code>% 95% CI) lower variability. This pattern
looks qualitatively similar with or without individuals targeting salmon. As
examples, variability was highest for the herring roe gillnet and king crab
fisheries. Most of the strategies with the lowest estimated revenue variability
combined halibut with a salmon permit and had high levels of fished species
diversity (Fig. \ref{fig:across}).</p>

<p>Comparing single permit holders to individuals holding that same permit plus
additional permits illustrates the expected reduction in revenue variability
from purchasing additional permits (Fig. \ref{fig:spokes}, Fig.
S\ref{fig:spoke-all}). For example, individuals fishing a halibut longline
permit plus one additional permit always had lower expected revenue variability
compared to individuals fishing only a halibut longline permit (median reduction
of <code>r 100-spoke[[2]]</code>% [<code>r 100-spoke[[3]]</code>--<code>r 100-spoke[[1]]</code>% IQR], Fig.
\ref{fig:spokes}A). Likewise, adding a permit to a herring roe gillnet strategy
substantially reduced expected revenue variability (Fig. \ref{fig:spokes}B).
Adding permits also usually increased expected revenue, although the permits
themselves represent a significant expense (e.g. TODO).</p>

<p>In contrast to the clear across-strategy effects of species diversity on revenue
and revenue variability, the effect of changing fished species diversity for an
individual <em>within</em> the constraints of a given permit set is more variable (Fig.
\ref{fig:within}). After accounting for fishing effort (Fig. S\ref{fig:fe}),
specializing (decreasing species diversity) tends to be associated with
increased revenue (~0.5% increased revenue per 1% decrease in species diversity
on average or TODO ... <code>r g2_dens</code>% probability; Fig. \ref{fig:within}). This is
particularly clear for permits where individuals tend to specialize on sockeye
salmon. For example, individuals with setnet permits for salmon in Prince
William Sound, Cook Inlet, Kodiak, Bristol Bay, or the Alaska Peninsula target
primarily sockeye salmon and experience a ~1.5% increase in revenue for a 1%
decrease in fished species diversity (Fig. \ref{fig:within}B). The converse is
also usually true --- generalizing tends to be associated with lower expected
revenue after accounting for fishing effort (i.e. Fig. \ref{fig:within}A and
\ref{fig:within}B are near mirror images left to right). This benefit of
specializing is only apparent after accounting for fishing effort. Given that
fishing for more species tends to be associated with increased fishing effort
(fishing more days), generalizing tends to be associated with higher revenue
when not standardizing for days finished (Fig. S-TODO). </p>

<p>After accounting for fishing effort, adjusting (increasing or decreasing) an
individual's fished species diversity from year-to-year within the constraints
of a permit set tends to be associated with greater expected variability or
uncertainty in year-to-year revenue (Fig. \ref{fig:within} strategies above 0;
Fig. S\ref{fig:fe}). This effect was strongest for individuals with a halibut
longline permit or halibut and sablefish longline permits. Individuals with
these strategies experienced ~2% increase in standardized variability for a 1%
change in fished species diversity (Fig. \ref{fig:within}). Levels of fished
species diversity levels above one for these permits are primarily due to
bycatch. </p>

<p>The Alaskan halibut and sablefish fisheries were converted to an individual
fishery quota (IFQ) system in 1994. This catch share system... TODO. We refit
our models allowing all permit-level effects to vary separately before and after
the introduction of IFQs for strategies involving halibut and sablefish permits.
The introduction of IFQs reduced variability by ~25% (XX--XX 95% CI) for
individuals with only halibut or sablefish permits (Fig. S\ref{fig:ifq}A).
Furthermore, for most strategies, the effect of increased revenue variability
associated with changing species diversity became stronger after the
introduction of IFQs (Fig. S\ref{fig:ifq}B). This was especially true for
individuals fishing only halibut or sablefish and less so for individuals
combining halibut or sable fish with a salmon permit (Fig. S\ref{fig:ifq}B).</p>

<h1><a id="user-content-discussion" class="anchor" href="#discussion" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Discussion</h1>

<h3><a id="user-content-take-homes--summary" class="anchor" href="#take-homes--summary" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Take homes / summary</h3>

<ul>
<li>Suggests it's mostly an across strategy/permit effect (lowering variability),
which isn't always a possibility because of regulations and cost</li>
<li>Adjusting within current permit constraints is risky... Not clearly risk
reducing to generalize from one year to the next</li>
<li>not as simple as increase diversity (within permit) and reduce risk</li>
<li>What's methodologically novel

<ul>
<li>Huge dataset</li>
<li>Permit level data (on individuals, not vessels)</li>
<li>Account for covariates</li>
<li>Accounting for strategies</li>
<li>Keeping annual data (not condensing to mean and cv)</li>
<li>Joint modelling of mean and variance</li>
<li>look at different mechanisms of diversification</li>
</ul></li>
<li>2 dimensions to think about (revenue and variability); and the trade-off is fishery specific

<ul>
<li>effects within a permit strategy are permit specific</li>
<li>Importantly it's a tradeoff - 2 dimensions - sometimes make more money by specializing... Some highly variable single species permits make a ton of money... which preferable?</li>
</ul></li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-reconciling-the-effects-at-different-levels-of-species-diversity" class="anchor" href="#reconciling-the-effects-at-different-levels-of-species-diversity" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Reconciling the effects at different levels of species diversity</h3>

<ul>
<li><p>How fit in with K and H?</p></li>
<li><p>EW: part of the difference is individuals vs vessels. For example, K&amp;H
suggested that diversity declined following IFQs for halibut sablefish
vessels. The reason for the decline was that the vessels were allowed to
fish halibut for more days (because people were sharing boats). At the level
of people, we wouldn't expect the diversity of someone who only had
halibut/sablefish permit to be affected by IFQs. The person, not the vessel
holds the quota share: <a href="https://alaskafisheries.noaa.gov/fisheries/ifq">https://alaskafisheries.noaa.gov/fisheries/ifq</a></p></li>
<li>Year to year risky... But maybe evens out/better over time</li>
<li>diversity within permit - often bycatch, limited room for intentional diversification (unless you have a M or salmon permit)</li>
<li>Risk results not really risk, but unpredictability given our covariates ...
don't change anything and it's most predictable how well you'll do</li>
<li>What's unpredictable in our model, might be more predictable on a year to
year, species by species basis for individual permit holder</li>
<li>Equilibrium, average variability vs year to year effect for one person</li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-limitations--obvious-extensions" class="anchor" href="#limitations--obvious-extensions" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Limitations + obvious extensions</h3>

<ul>
<li>limitations...</li>
<li>Vary by time</li>
<li>Vary by mean diversity</li>
<li>Spatial variation</li>
<li>Nonlinear effects</li>
<li>Response to specific events like EVOS and ITQs</li>
</ul>

<h3><a id="user-content-implications-for-limited-entry-itqs-and-catch-shares" class="anchor" href="#implications-for-limited-entry-itqs-and-catch-shares" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Implications for limited entry, ITQs, and catch shares</h3>

<ul>
<li>if this is true, this is concerning because in many areas of the world and
fisheries, regulations and market forces have encouraged specialization</li>
<li>Permit diversity result: a privileged position - expensive to get to into
(quote king crab license)</li>
<li>Locking into permits limits ability to pick lower risk strategies and is
getting people locked into low diversity permits that may be doing well now,
but not necessarily always</li>
</ul>
